prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Sensitivity: We seek to image the entire field down to 250 microJy which takes about 10s per pointing in this mosaic.
We are interested in getting the continuum flux at each point and have set up the correlator in the Band 6 continuum mode.

After simulating different spacings of a mosaic we choose a spacing of 0.68 x primary beam to give us the best trade off between a fairly uniform sensitivity(~10-15% corrugation of the sensitivity) and a large mosaic.
There is no non-standard choice for the continuum frequency.
We do not intend to resolve sources and therefore request a coarse resolution of 1 arcsecond which is sufficient to avoid source confusion and yet isolate all the galaxies in the field.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: P2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: P1 - P4 move to the right and stack going up..

After simulating different spacings of a mosaic we choose a spacing of 0.68 x primary beam to give us the best trade off between a fairly uniform sensitivity(~10-15% corrugation of the sensitivity) and a large mosaic.
There is no non-standard choice for the continuum frequency.
We do not intend to resolve sources and therefore request a coarse resolution of 1 arcsecond which is sufficient to avoid source confusion and yet isolate all the galaxies in the field.

There is no non-standard choice for the continuum frequency.
We do not intend to resolve sources and therefore request a coarse resolution of 1 arcsecond which is sufficient to avoid source confusion and yet isolate all the galaxies in the field.
Sensitivity: We seek to image the entire field down to 250 microJy which takes about 10s per pointing in this mosaic.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose an innovative 0.25 degree wide area 1.3mm survey with ALMA reaching 300uJy (rms) in the COSMOS field. This unique data set is an ideal complement to the Cycle-1 HUDF and will enable joint evolutionary studies of the interstellar medium mass (derived from the ALMA data) with the stellar mass, star formation rate, large scale structure, and dark matter haloes of galaxies over the majority of cosmic time (0.5<z<6). These studies are uniquely enabled by the wide area, providing >350 individual sources, and deep ancillary data sets in COSMOS that provide >250,000 objects with stellar masses, redshifts, and other properties. Such a large number of well characterized objects means one can measure average ALMA fluxes 10-100 times deeper than the individual detection for almost any property bin by stacking the ALMA data, reaching ISM masses as low as 4e9 Msun, comparable to the present day ISM mass in the Milky Way. Furthermore, these stacking studies will be able to leverage the 8x larger samples available over the full COSMOS field to correlate properties such as dark matter halo mass and large-scale structure properties with ALMA-derived interstellar medium masses.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
